title: Acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan to Step Down

summary: Android creator was bought out of the venture-capital firm he co-founded. Android software creator Andy Rubin has left Playground Global, the venture-capital firm he co-founded, a person familiar with the matter said.

title: The Turk and the President
summary: The Syrian retreat is all too typical of Trump's decision-making.. President Trump prides himself on one-on-one diplomacy, but too often it results in rash and damaging decisions like his abrupt order Sunday for U.S. troops to retreat from northern Syria. Turkish strongman Recep Tayyip Erdogan is now dictating terms to the American President, and the consequences are likely to be felt far beyond Syria and Turkey.

summary: Now he wants to use the tax code to punish religious dissenters.. Former Texas Congressman Beto O'Rourke, in his effort to become relevant in a crowded field of progressives, has outdone himself again. Last month he endorsed a mandatory gun buyback ("Hell yes, we're going to take your AR-15"). Now he's ready to punish churches for failing to embrace the progressive cultural agenda.

summary: The $7,500 tax credit is going to many buyers who don't qualify.. The biggest financial companies that Facebook Inc. recruited to launch a world-wide cryptocurrency-based payments network have backed out of the project, threatening to derail an ambitious initiative to remake global finance before it ever gets off the ground.

summary: Civil servants too often forget they work for the people and seek to impose their own policy agendas.. It's as if the whole effort is designed to confirm President Trump's complaint that the "deep state" is determined to sabotage his presidency.

title: Do California's Blackouts Make Sense?
summary: Some 90% of wildfires are not caused by power lines. How does cutting power help fight them?. When Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell isn't worried about trade wars, he can now worry about substantial chunks of gross domestic product going offline for days at a time thanks to California's intentional electricity blackouts.

title: Social-Justice Warriors Won't Listen, but You Should
summary: To counter extreme views, it's necessary for you to understand them-and that they're sincerely held.. It would be charming for advocates of social-justice ideology to say, "We need to have a conversation," were they not almost uniformly such dreadful conversationalists. If they'll converse with you at all, you might hear that any disagreement with them is a sign of your inherent weakness ("white fragility," Robin DiAngelo), of your intentional refusal to engage honestly ("pernicious ignorance," Kristie Dotson), or of your unreasonable expectation that someone do your homework for you ("epistemic exploitation," Nora Berenstain). You might find yourself accused of complicity in white supremacy (Barbara Applebaum) or misogyny (Kate Manne), both understood in an obscure "systemic" sense, though of course the words retain the damning connotations rightly associated with their literal meanings.

title: 'Music' Review: Posterity Without Pedestals
summary: Even Bach was once a rule-breaker, whose bold music disturbed Leipzig's austere Lutherans.. In 1999 the great pianist, bandleader and composer Duke Ellington would have been 100. As editor of a jazz magazine at the time, I marked the occasion with an essay by Don Byron, a clarinetist whose music to that point had included both his own bold original compositions and faithful readings of early Ellington works. Mr. Byron wrote of "reveling in" and "dreading" the Ellington centennial. The source of his dread? "A truckload of roasted corn heading for a concert hall near you," as he put it; Ellington as "our own American Beethoven," proof of jazz's legitimacy among great arts. Such canonization, he worried, would ensure that "the Ellington I know and love will probably never come to light." His Ellington had a sense of "ugly beauty" and made a brilliant career of "sneaking in the outest stuff he could think of and, mysteriously, making people like it"-like the "skronked-out interlude that precedes Harry Carney's baritone saxophone solo on 'Jack the Bear.' " Mr. Byron wanted to remind readers that Ellington "was a true subversive. We need to hear him, not put him on a pedestal."

title: 'The Topeka School' Review: Lost Boys on the Prairie
summary: For his third novel, Ben Lerner expands his canvas to produce a polyphonic portrait of an entire community, yet never strays far from the autobiographical.. Ben Lerner, at age 40, has nothing to be embarrassed about: He is a MacArthur Fellow, one of Granta's Best Young American Novelists, and one of the most acclaimed writers in the English-speaking world. Yet to read his first two novels is to squirm with vicarious embarrassment-not only because his characters are embarrassed by frank displays of sincerity, but also because his characters' very embarrassment is itself embarrassing. In "Leaving the Atocha Station," Mr. Lerner's masterly 2011 debut, his narrator and alter-ego Adam Gordon watches a man weeping in the Prado. "Was he," Adam wonders, "just facing the wall to hide his face as he dealt with whatever grief he'd brought into the museum? Or was he having a profound experience of art?" Adam, a would-be poet who cannot bring himself to write any poems, is skeptical that profound experiences of art really exist-though he is desperate to believe that they do, which is why he has written such an ambivalent novel about them. Like Adam, we are embarrassed for the man who cries but also horrified by the man who can't.

title: First Parent to Avoid Prison in College-Admissions Scandal
summary: Judge credits Bay Area father for not hiding his payment as charitable donation. BOSTON-A Bay Area father is the first to avoid prison in the nationwide college-admissions scandal, after a federal judge credited him for not hiding his payment as a charitable donation.

title: Ukrainians vs. the Swamp
summary: Encouraging signs that someday the country might not even tolerate a Hunter Biden deal.. Call this column optimistic. But there's reason to believe that indefensible deals like paying fortunes to unqualified sons of foreign politicians will someday be just as difficult to pull off in Ukraine as they are in the United States. In fact, recent developments suggest that Ukrainian leaders may help us improve American government even as they improve their own national governance.

summary: Shares of the iPhone maker clinched a new closing high. The past year has been a mixed bag for the popular "FAANG" stocks, but one of the "A's" is back on track.

He was better known, though, for his creative tactics in recruiting lawyers to join the Los Angeles-based firm where he was a partner, Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan.

title: Plucked From Life
summary: Bernardo Strozzi's 'The Cook' is revolutionary in its humble subject matter and very human protagonist.. What could be more Italian than a cook? Food in Italy is, after all, a source of national pride, nearly as celebrated as its broad, deep, virtuosic artistic achievements. Yet when Bernardo Strozzi (c. 1581-1644) combined the two in his painting "The Cook" (c. 1625), he ignited a conflagration.

summary: Newly signed law will force federal government to shut down four facilities for migrants in state. California will work to end the use of private prisons within its borders, including for-profit immigrant detention facilities, under a law signed Friday by Gov. Gavin Newsom.

title: Diagnoses of the State of Cancer Treatments
summary: A rational approach to early cancer detection could include focusing on individuals who have the highest genetic predisposition to cancer or tumor types with the longest lead times to metastasis.. As an early-cancer-detection researcher, I applaud Azra Raza's critique of the therapy-centric approach to cancer management ("Cancer Is Still Beating Us: We Need a New Start," Review, Oct. 5).

title: Sports Illustrated Prospered When It Was Mostly Sports
summary: Editors decided to drift away from reporting strictly on the sports world and became an active participant in social activism.. Regarding Bob Greene's "When Sports Illustrated Was Great" (op-ed, Oct. 9) lamenting the demise of Sports Illustrated, I suggest he should look further back than the corporate takeovers, restructuring and deaths of prominent SI individuals. I also revered Sports Illustrated as a young boy, teenager and adult. I wasn't a hoarder but I read each issue cover to cover and eventually came to the realization that SI lost its way. Editors decided to drift away from reporting strictly on the sports world and began publishing pieces on social activism, politics and opinion. Sports Illustrated's original mission became an afterthought as it focused more and more on the cause du jour. That's when I canceled my subscription, as did many others. I lamented its passing long ago.

title: Bureaucrats for Homeless Have the Wrong Incentives
summary: The primary beneficiaries of the money spent on San Francisco's homelessness problem are the people handing out the needles and the jerky.. Regarding the letters of Oct. 10 responding to Heather Mac Donald's "The Streets of San Francisco" (op-ed, Oct. 4): If you want to make a problem permanent, put a bureaucracy in charge of solving it. The primary beneficiaries of the money spent on San Francisco's homelessness problem are the people handing out the needles and the jerky. They have no incentive to eliminate the problem-they have every incentive to make the problem larger. The more homelessness, the bigger the budget, the larger the bureaucracy, the more levels of management and the greater the opportunity for bumped pension benefits and seniority-based advancement. Think like a government employee and there is no mystery about the intractability of San Francisco's problem.

title: China's Old Debt to the U.S.
summary: The Chinese would be speaking Japanese now were it not for the good old U.S.A.. Regarding Elbridge Colby's "Don't Let Iran Distract From China" (op-ed, Sept. 25): And to think the Chinese would be speaking Japanese now were it not for the good old U.S.A. Xi Jinping must have a short memory. Perhaps our president should remind him.

title: GM Talks With UAW Hit Impasse, Propelling Strike Into the Weekend

title: Range Rover's New Hybrid: Already Five Years Behind the Curve
summary: With techy car brands like Tesla pushing all-electric range well past 200 miles, the Range Rover Sport PHEV's estimated 25-mile ability falls woefully short. Dan Neil takes it for a spin. In 2006, the car transporter Cougar Ace tipped on its side in the North Pacific, scrapping a shipment of 4,700 Mazdas. And in March of this year the Grande America caught fire and sank off the coast of France, consigning its load of Audis and Porsches-including a clutch of GT2 RS supercars-to the briny deep.

title: Streaming Is Killing Physical Media. Here's Why You Won't Miss It.
summary: With Samsung's decision to stop making Blu-ray players, now even discs are going extinct. One writer reminisces about all we'll lose. Another looks forward to an all-digital future. AT THE END of a long and draining day, my favorite thing to do is slowly flip through my overstuffed binder of DVDs and Blu-rays.

title: Ukraine Tries to Build a New Identity
summary: Long in Russia's shadow, the country has rejected ethnic politics in favor of inclusion, economic growth and cultural diversity. When President Volodymyr Zelensky was slated to open the annual Yalta European Strategy conference in Kyiv last month, he yielded the honor to Ukraine's new national hero, filmmaker Oleh Sentsov. Just released from five years in Russian captivity as part of a prisoner swap, Mr. Sentsov brought the audience to tears as he recounted how he had struggled with his jailers to hold on to a prized possession: a plastic jar decorated with Ukraine's blue-and-yellow colors. He ended by holding up the jar, to thunderous applause.

summary: Looking ahead to the day when the league finally takes a stand against...Indiana.. Dateline: New York, Feb. 24, 2020

title: A Norway Cruise That Offers Flexibility and Very Little Fuss
summary: On a series of cruise-like ferry trips up Norway's coastline, a visitor hops on and off as she likes, seeking out snug spots with overwhelming views. HURTIGRUTEN MEANS "fast route" in Norwegian, and the company's ferry trips up its home coast are certainly that-in seven days, the boat pulls into 34 harbors. I too had a tight schedule, with just a few days to explore a country with 15,626 miles of coastline and 50,000 islands. Though I made it to only three ports, I did cross the Arctic Circle and get a taste of life in the northern latitudes, where one of Hurtigruten's 11 large ferry ships makes this trip virtually every day of the year.

title: AI Could Prevent Marital Arguments Before They Even Begin
summary: Researchers use listening devices and algorithms to detect speech patterns that typically precede fights. Couples often find themselves in familiar arguments that escalate and repeat. Artificial intelligence may be able to help.

title: How to Build Robots People Can Relate To
summary: Resume Subscription. When creating relationships with people, humans are wired to look for personality-a bond that we can discover and relate to. We want to understand the other person and be understood in return.

title: The FBI Lost Our Son
summary: Resume Subscription. William and Theresa Reilly were biking on a leafy trail north of Detroit when their son, Billy, sent a text from his trip to Russia. The 28-year-old man had never lived away from home, and the Reillys fretted over his safe return.

title: 'Plagued by Fire' Review: The Spirit in the Form
summary: A preacher's son, a small-town man at heart, Frank Lloyd Wright created secular cathedrals that seem to hover like recently landed spaceships, defying gravity.. Even when you grant how exposed to the elements an architect's work may be, Frank Lloyd Wright appears to have been an insurer's nightmare. If a building could shake, burn or flood, time and again Wright's structures did. Like the exquisite Rose Pauson House in Phoenix, which lasted a mere year before succumbing to fire. Or the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo, with its gorgeous H-shaped guest wing, rocked by an earthquake on the day it opened. The Johnson Wax building in Racine, Wis., was so porous that office staff were known to keep buckets by their desk on rainy days.

title: The Ultimate Learning Machines
summary: The future of artificial intelligence depends on designing computers that can think and explore as resourcefully as babies do.. Last July, I went to the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), the blue-sky government research lab that helped to invent the computer and the internet. I was there, strange as it may seem, to talk about babies. The latest big DARPA research project, Machine Common Sense, is funding collaborations between child psychologists like me and computer scientists. This year I also talked about children's minds at Google, Facebook and Apple.

title: An Ad Giant Struggles To Sell Its Story
summary: Publicis, which owns brands like Leo Burnett and Sapient, has misstepped in its digital transformation. Results season has got off to an alarming start in the advertising industry, but investors shouldn't get the wrong message.

title: 'Possessed by Memory' and 'The American Canon' Review: A Cat That Walks by Himself
summary: Harold Bloom likes to portray himself as a weary critical Prometheus, assailed by flocks of eagles.. Along with less striking literary tchotchkes, I own a framed picture of Harold Bloom. It was a gift from the late Alice K. Turner, the longtime fiction editor of Playboy and a midlife student of Mr. Bloom's when, for a brief time, the celebrated critic taught at New York University as well as Yale. That Alice, tough-minded and nobody's fool, revered "Harold" suggests something of his astonishing intellectual charisma.

summary: Billy Reilly sourcing.

title: Five Best: Caitlin Horrocks on Biographical Novels About Artists
summary: The author, most recently, of the novel "The Vexations," selects fictional works about real creative lives.. By Ron Hansen (2008)

title: 'The Body' Review: The Magnificent Machine
summary: Evolution runs on imperfect 'make-do,' Bill Bryson stresses. Humans learned to walk upright, at the cost of fragile joints and clog-prone sinuses.. No one can fault Bill Bryson for lack of ambition. He has written tales of travel on four continents, a biography of Shakespeare, a history of the English language and, in the modestly titled "A Short History of Nearly Everything," a summing-up of the present state of scientific knowledge.

title: 'The Nature of Life and Death' Review: The Queen of Forensic Science
summary: Patricia Wiltshire helps find perpetrators by analyzing the dust, dirt and pollen they leave at crime scenes.. I've long been a sucker for that crime-fiction stereotype, the old lady sleuth who defies social expectations by being clever and fearless. The nosy Miss Marple, the curious Jessica Fletcher, the cozy Miss Maud Silver-they all have in common an independence, a kind of postmenopausal unflappability and an infinite capacity to upend the assumptions of condescending cops and criminals. So it was with great delight that I met the real thing in the pages of Patricia Wiltshire's fascinating memoir "The Nature of Life and Death: Every Body Leaves a Trace."

title: Fiction: Life Without Illusions in Crosby, Maine
summary: The return of the tart-tongued Olive Kitteridge, who remains as brutally candid with herself as she is with others.. It may be that we have been getting the idea of empathy all wrong. The concept, today celebrated as one of the highest virtues in liberal society, seems to have been subtly redefined to signify something closer to sympathy. Reading fiction cultivates empathy, we're told; that is, it helps us feel pity for people less fortunate than ourselves. In a recent essay, the Zambian novelist Namwali Serpell criticized the narcissism of the dynamic, observing that "the empathy model of art can bleed too easily into the relishing of suffering by those who are safe from it." In this model, literature is fundamentally therapeutic; it offers a quick fix of emotional catharsis.

title: Brexit Talks to Intensify as Prospect of Deal Improves
summary: The pound surged Thursday on the prospect of a deal and continued to rise following Donald Tusk's remarks. European Union and U.K. officials will intensify Brexit talks in an attempt to reach an agreement on Britain's split from the bloc before a leaders' summit next week, fueling hopes that a yearlong impasse over Britain's departure from the trade bloc may soon end.

title: Mysteries: Getting Pragmatic With the Law
summary: The gregarious Constable Peregrine Twitten annoys his colleagues with pesky questions about the apparent suicide of a Brighton beachgoer.. English writer Lynne Truss's "The Man That Got Away" (Bloomsbury, 281 pages, $17) is a worthy follow-up to her delightful 2018 novel "A Shot in the Dark." Ms. Truss's new work again takes place in the seaside resort of Brighton in 1957 and focuses on the novice Constable Peregrine Twitten, "a keen amateur social anthropologist (and incorrigible know-all)" whose "quickness of mind combined with his inability to shut up about anything-ever." Unsurprisingly, Twitten proves more than irksome to his boss, Inspector Steine-a man with "an almost superhuman capacity for accepting things at face value" and a compulsion to stamp as many cases as possible "unsolved."

title: 'The Greatest Fury' Review: Redcoats on the Run
summary: The War of 1812 was already over, but victory at New Orleans filled the young U.S. with swagger and a sense of destiny.. In January 1815, the fledgling United States won a stunning victory over British redcoats on a plantation field near New Orleans. Fought shortly after a treaty was signed in Belgium ending the war, Andrew Jackson's signature win gave swagger to a young nation that had been whipped in Canada, pushed back in Maine, and made to endure the shame of seeing its capital engulfed in flames lit by British troops. Jackson's outnumbered menagerie-militiamen, pirates, freed slaves, Choctaw Indians, farmers, backwoodsmen and Army regulars-thrashed the best of the British army with a storm of lead and iron. When the smoke drifted away, the British commanders, Gens. Edward Pakenham and Samuel Gibbs, lay dead among the 2,000 British casualties, a quarter of the British force. American losses: some 60 men.

title: Children's Books: Goblins, Dragons, Trolls-and Some Humans Too
summary: Celebrating myths and fables from Scotland, England, Ireland, Norway, Switzerland, Korea and even more countries.. Once upon a time, the world was without electronics, and people had to come up with entertainment on their own. One of the ways they did this was by telling stories: funny stories, sinister stories, cautionary tales, all sorts of narratives that they passed along one person to another, one generation to another. Today we encounter folk and fairy tales mostly in written form, thanks in part to the diligence of folklorists who sought to collect as many stories as possible before the tradition of oral storytelling died away. Of these, the most famous are Wilhelm and Jacob Grimm, but as a tranche of wonderful new collections reminds us, the Brothers Grimm had lots of company.

title: 'Kangaroo Court': A Peculiar Complaint of Unjust Proceedings
summary: The expression used by President Trump to denounce impeachment seems to come from the antebellum American South, with a dark connection to lynching. When President Trump announced that the White House would not cooperate with the impeachment inquiry in the Democratic-led House of Representatives, he painted the probe into his dealings with Ukraine as an unfair, partisan attack on the presidency. Adding color to the accusation, Mr. Trump and supporters have used a phrase long associated with miscarriages of justice: "kangaroo court."

OTTAWA-Canada's labor market posted another strong advance in September and the unemployment rate unexpectedly fell, fueling expectations the Bank of Canada will leave interest rates on hold in its upcoming decision.

title: Why U.S. Businesses Want Trustbusting
summary: The loudest complaints against today's monopolies come not from Occupy Wall Street types but from leaders of firms seeking freedom of commerce. Trustbusting is back, and it's a bipartisan effort. Last month, 50 state attorneys general, led by the conservative Republican Ken Paxton of Texas, announced an investigation of Google for anticompetitive conduct. Republican Sen. Josh Hawley of Missouri has been a fierce critic of big tech, as has the Democratic-led House Judiciary Committee, which is probing the sector. Several Democratic presidential candidates have pledged to address the problem of concentrated power not just in tech but in agriculture, defense and media too.

title: Investors Approve UTC-Raytheon Merger
summary: The $135 billion combination will create the world's second-largest defense company pending regulatory approval. Shareholders backed the creation of one of the world's largest aerospace companies on Friday, voting in favor of the $135 billion combination of United Technologies Corp. and Raytheon Co.

title: The NBA's China Foul Is a Fresh Lesson in Foreign Political Risk
summary: As pressure builds on firms to address social issues, a single tweet by a basketball executive illustrates the potential costs to having a corporate conscience. Executives are under pressure to speak up on social issues they once avoided-like LGBTQ rights or climate change-because employees, customers and investors have begun to demand it.

title: Can a $450 Overcoat Pass for a $3,450 One? A Tailoring Experiment
summary: Thick, tweedy "Mad Men" men's coats-from luxe labels like Givenchy and Celine-are in style again. We took a bargain vintage piece to a tailor to see if he could approximate the new fit. I DON'T KNOW if my late grandfather actually owned a tweed topcoat. I remember him best after he had settled into a retiree's wardrobe of maximum comfort: gray down-filled coats and nylon Windbreakers. Yet, this January, sitting at the invigoratingly contemporary Celine fall 2019 fashion show in Paris, as a cavalcade of men wearing classic shin-skimming coats in houndstooths and Prince of Wales checks walked by, I thought improbably of Irving Nurik, my mother's father. Minus the tight jeans and the models' graphic haircuts, the looks seemed like ones my grandfather could have worn crossing the college quad as a student in the 1950s or en route to his teaching job in the '60s. This type of boxy tweed overcoat was a staple for men across multiple continents during the entire midcentury period.

title: Can an AI System Be Given a Patent?
summary: An artificially intelligent system purportedly has created two new products. Now patent offices must decide if it can be named as the inventor.. If an artificially intelligent system creates a new product, should patent offices recognize it as the inventor?

title: Trump Makes Joe Biden's Son a Top Campaign Target
summary: 'I want to see Hunter,' he tells crowd at Minnesota rally, mocking the younger Biden as 'not too smart'. President Trump took aim at the son of former Vice President Joe Biden, ridiculing the 49-year-old as a loser, accusing him of profiting off his father's name and turning him into a campaign prop during a rally in Minnesota on Thursday.

title: New York Fed Adds $82.7 Billion To Financial System in Latest Repo Transaction
summary: The Fed began offering repo loans last month after a shortage of available cash in the financial system led rates to climb. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $82.7 billion to the financial system Friday, using the market for repurchase agreements, or repo, to relieve funding pressure in money markets.

summary: The prize recognized the leader's efforts to achieve peace with neighboring Eritrea. Ethiopia's prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for his work toward ending a 20-year conflict with neighboring Eritrea and opening up one of Africa's most notorious one-party systems.

title: Languages of Pure Form and Color
summary: Pierre Bonnard and Édouard Vuillard charted art's course toward abstraction. In 1891, the young painters Pierre Bonnard (1867-1947) and Édouard Vuillard (1868-1940) shared a Paris studio, where they took a crucial step toward the invention of abstract art. But their contribution is often overshadowed by the legacy of the impressionists who preceded them and the modernists they anticipated. Starting Oct. 26, the Phillips Collection in Washington, D.C. will attempt to change that with a new exhibition, "Bonnard to Vuillard: The Intimate Poetry of Everyday Life."

title: Hugo Boss Is a Bad Fit for a Weaker Economy
summary: The stock market valuations of premium fashion brands and true luxury are diverging. Spending at companies like Hugo Boss is drying up more quickly than at ultraluxury brands. Premium fashion labels will be especially vulnerable in the next economic downturn.

PARIS- Renault SA fired Chief Executive Thierry Bolloré as the French car maker seeks to turn the page on Carlos Ghosn's decades of leadership and reboot its globe-spanning alliance with Nissan Motor Co.

title: Astros, Yankees Set for a Heavyweight Clash
summary: Houston was pushed to the brink by Tampa Bay, but its elite starting pitching, led by Gerrit Cole, is why the Astros are still the team to beat. HOUSTON-The Tampa Bay Rays pushed the Houston Astros to the brink of humiliation, a scrappy underdog with a microscopic payroll forcing baseball's best team to fight for its life. They drew blood against a foe that looked all but invincible and conjured visions of a historic division series upset.

summary: A challenge from technology's greatest showman led Marc Benioff to a breakthrough insight about how to find true innovation at Salesforce.com.. I first met Steve Jobs in 1984 when Apple Inc. hired me as a summer intern.

title: The Billionaire, the Olympian and the Quest for the Sub-2-Hour Marathon
summary: How the obsessions of Jim Ratcliffe and Eliud Kipchoge aligned for Saturday's attempt on one of running's last barriers. VIENNA-The original plan was to help a British sailing team challenge for the America's Cup. Then the plan was also to win the Tour de France. And after that, the plan expanded to buying a soccer club on the French Riviera.

title: GOP Senators' Concerns Muddy Impeachment Path
summary: McConnell suggests chamber could dispense with articles quickly, but his party might not vote as a bloc. WASHINGTON-Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has suggested that a vote by the Democratic-controlled House to impeach President Trump could be quickly dispensed with in his chamber. One way to do that: The Republican-controlled Senate could vote on a motion to dismiss the charges without a trial.

title: A Bite-Size Trade Deal Won't Save U.S. Industry
summary: China and President Trump would benefit from a truce focused on food purchases, but investors risk overestimating the economic impact. President Trump has long claimed he wanted a big deal with China. There is no sign of that, but a mini-deal that takes tensions down a notch without addressing fundamental issues looks increasingly possible. Markets are celebrating but investors shouldn't overestimate the impact outside of a few sectors like agriculture.

title: Shooter in German Synagogue Attack Confesses
summary: Stephan Ballier admitted anti-Semitic and Right-wing extremist motives in attack that killed two in Halle, Germany. BERLIN-The German man charged with murder in Wednesday's botched attack on a synagogue has confessed to the crime and admitted to anti-Semitic and far-right-wing extremist motives, the federal prosecutor's office said.

title: A Private-Equity Partnership With Richard Branson Stalls
summary: London-based credit firm Metric Capital planned to raise $500 million to back consumer-facing companies. Early last year, John Sinik, managing partner of London-based private-credit firm Metric Capital Partners referred to Virgin Group founder Richard Branson as "one of the greatest entrepreneurs of our lifetime."

summary: After increasing 10-fold between 1950 and 2010, average residential consumption dipped. For more than five years, Americans have been doing something decidedly un-American: We've been using less electricity.

title: UBS Prime Brokerage Executive Chris Hagstrom to Leave Bank
summary: Departure comes after 15 years amid revamping of bank's equities and fixed-income divisions. Senior UBS Group AG executive Chris Hagstrom will leave the bank amid a restructuring of the equities and fixed-income divisions, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Artist Rachel Feinstein's Favorite Things
summary: The painter and sculptor shares the personal objects that inspire her most, including a 100-carat ring her husband, artist John Currin, once gave her. "The feathers signify my mother, who's passionate about saving the wild parrots of South Florida-where I grew up-from poachers. I don't understand my mother's obsession with parrots. They frighten me. The photo is of my dad walking me down the aisle at my wedding, on Valentine's Day, 1998. He just passed away. He was a dermatologist, so my pale skin has aged pretty well thanks to him. Those are shells of oysters that John [Currin, her artist husband] and I ate at Masa, the Japanese restaurant in New York that we go to for our wedding anniversary every year. Inside one shell is a 100-carat blue aquamarine ring that John bought for me in 2003. The book on the left is Maids, Madonnas, & Witches: Women in Sculpture From Prehistoric Times to Picasso, with photographs by Andreas Feininger. It's gorgeous, and it inspired Rachel Feinstein: Maiden, Mother, Crone, my new show at the Jewish Museum in New York, and my new Rizzoli book, Rachel Feinstein. The flower girl sculpture was based on The Snow Queen, a trippy, weird story by Hans Christian Andersen. I made it out of Sculpey, which is a bakeable clay, with help from my sons. It was the basis for a large piece at my 2011 show at the Lever House. I made that shoe in Nymphenburg, a famous old porcelain factory in Munich. It's a test sample for a 2018 pedestal piece called Corrine. John made a painting of me, called Rachel in Fur, where I'm wearing those huge sunglasses, which are by Cutler and Gross. That small bronze sculpture is a cast of my finger that has testicles hanging from it. It's my power finger. The white-paper model sculpture I based on a surreal, frightening drawing that my oldest son, Francis, did when he was 10, after he was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes. It was a horrible experience, and it's a deeply personal sculpture. The other book is French Scenic Wallpaper 1795-1865. It's like my bible. And in back, that's my dog, Mr. Greenjeans, an affenpinscher. He's my spirit animal. He sleeps right by my side, and John likes to joke that Mr. Greenjeans actually thinks that he-the dog-is my husband."

summary: WSJ. editor in chief Kristina O'Neill introduces the October 2019 Style & Tech, including why industry icons Demi Moore, Naomi Campbell and Bob Iger are all so captivating. title: She Took a Two-Year Break in Her Career. Now She's CEO.
summary: Deanna Mulligan of Guardian Life Insurance talks about how time off helped her find new focus. When she was 41 years old, Deanna Mulligan stepped back from the prime of her career. Now CEO of Guardian Life Insurance, Ms. Mulligan reflects on that move, and what it taught her-among other things, that "life is not a straight line." What follows is an edited version of her reflections, as told to Wall Street Journal reporter Chip Cutter.

title: These Counties Voted for Every White House Winner Since Reagan
summary: Resume Subscription. At a time of deep political division in the American electorate, a small group of counties across the nation has shown extraordinary political flexibility, voting for the winner in every presidential election since 1980.

title: Who Willed the Electric Car? China, and Here's Why
summary: Electric vehicles that derive their power from dirty energy aren't necessarily better for the environment, but they are better for Beijing. Exxon Mobil Chief Executive Officer Darren Woods recently took a shot at electric vehicles. Speaking at the Oil and Gas Climate Initiative late last month, he quipped that their purpose could be defeated if the vehicles are powered by electricity derived from burning coal.

title: Growth Plan Pits Mountain Bikers Against Suburban Expansion
summary: Proposed quarry extension would provide needed building materials; residents petition to keep wooded area next to state park. RALEIGH, N.C.-A proposed rock quarry on public land popular with mountain bikers has exposed a fault line over growth in this booming region.

title: GOP Voters Tell Lawmakers to Stick With Trump
summary: At gatherings with GOP congressmen, Republicans criticize impeachment probe, but Democrats press representatives to back investigation. BLAINE, Minn.-GOP Rep. Tom Emmer's opposition to the House impeachment probe fueled a heated town hall meeting with constituents here, with Democrats urging him to stand up to the president while the three-term congressman blamed them for looking for a reason to attack President Trump.

title: Mutual Funds' Embrace of High-Profile Unicorns Backfires
summary: Looking to beat benchmarks, funds expanded their holdings of private tech startups only to mark down values after disappointing IPOs. Mutual funds that invested billions in big technology startups are now suffering losses in newly public companies and are being forced to mark down their holdings of private companies that are no longer investor darlings.

title: Congress Looks at Helping Ukraine Get Its Act Together
summary: Lawmakers discuss funding an investigative unit in Kyiv's military, and Arizona GOP worries about senator's fundraising. AN INSPECTOR GENERAL-FOR UKRAINE? Congress considers funding for an investigative unit inside the Ukrainian military. A bipartisan delegation to Kyiv discussed the idea with Ukrainian officials earlier this month as the impeachment drama-sparked by a whistleblower report to the IG for the U.S. intelligence community-swirled in Washington. Members on the trip tiptoed around talking about the impeachment inquiry and instead discussed Ukraine's efforts to deal with corruption, especially in the military.

title: Publicis Shares Plunge After Ad Giant Cuts Guidance
summary: French firm says industry upheaval will weigh on growth this year. PARIS-Shares in Publicis Groupe SA plunged Friday after the advertising giant lowered its guidance for the second time in a year, stoking fears about the ad industry's ability to cope with a host of challenges including the increasing dominance of tech giants.
